svg.title: combi

g.desc:
Evacuated tube panels allow sun to heat water, water is circulated to storage during daylight. Drained back at night (and summer)
Stratification allows coldest water to be heated continually
One or two initially expandable to four
g.title: solar hot water panels

text.desc:
additional volume can be added to the warm cistern by chaining hot output to cold input, and noving back solar input.
Each tank may be in the 2-300gal range. Initially one up to four.
text.title: additional warm cisterns

g.desc:
A coil, say 500ft, of 1" PEX is supended in the heat storage tank It is filled at one end by city cold water At the other it goes to a regular HW tank as preheated water
As the coil holds >10gal it should preheat most needs more extensive needs can be meet by condution. Even though PEX is a poor thermal conductor still the long length should be enough.
Ultimately the HW tank can be taken out of the loop and used as an addon to the heat storage cistern(s)
g.title: hot water subsystem

rect.desc:
An electrical storage system capable of powering 24v circulators
Initially could be quite small just a few car 12v batteries
ultimately could be a large system eg fro a Leaf, Volt or even hydrogen storage tanks, flywheels etc. Depends on future tech
rect.title: battery

g.desc: the inverter converts the DC of the battery/PV solar cells to AC. Output tapped at 24v to drive heating system doodads (the heating is robust against grid failure) and 120v for generic house use, and is fed back to the grid thus balancing the input to the battery by dumping excess
g.title: inverter

g.desc:
There are 45 linear feet of E/W rooftop What is not taken up by the water heaters could be filled with panels
Minimally it could be a small panel just enough to charge the battery for the pumps to drive the heating system
g.title: photo voltaic panels

g.desc: Double layer radiant flooring: Zones underneath and above webbing. The two layers have two time constants, fast for every day uses and slow to stretch out HW reserves.
g.title: houseHeat

g.desc: Temperature controlled mixing of in/out flows from cistern so the slab heat sink never rises above a given temp
g.title: Mixer

text.desc:
The controller is kind of openended. Initially it could, perhaps should, be just a timer of when the sun rises and sets. Reset manually seasonally.
More elaborately it could be a comercial device taking in sensors and outputing pump commands It should also log the sensors to a v-Bus device
Ultimately it will be a PC, eg an Android
text.title: controller

text.desc:
Says when the sun is up. A commercial calibrated pyranometer costs upwards of several hundred dollars. Really just a simple photocell, even the costly ones. A minimal calibration (no/sun) would work. Especially initially. Later the few % can be eeked out by finer calibration.
A timer which was manually shifte with the seasons would also do for control. But the wiring needs to be put in place for eventual sensor placement.
text.title: pyranometer

text.desc: Extant in the electrical baseboard heater system Coopt the device for hydronic solution
text.title: Thermostat

text.desc: each zone (and work bench) is controlled with its own solenoid
text.title: solenoids

text.desc: A set of temperatures to monitor tank parts could be muotiplied by the number of tanks At least on at the top and bottom of a tank
text.title: temperature

text.desc:
Pulls the heating fluid through Whichever zones are open by the controller switched on and off by the thermostat
Could be a DC pump powered by the solar cells (and battery when the sun is not up) These have an additional advantage of being cheaper and more durable
text.title: heating circulator

text.desc:
In an open drainback system one must intially overcome gravity till the panels are filled. Then it is easier as a siphon is established.
This can be accomplished by having a single (bigger) multispeed pump or two small pumps with one cutting out after a fixed delay
Could be DC pumps powered by the solar cells (and battery when the sun is not up) These have an additional advantage of being cheaper and more durable
text.title: panel circulator(s)
